attributes.title: Behavioral effects of descriptive representation -- Lab edition -- Vol 2

q1.value: Behavioral effects of descriptive representation -- Lab edition -- Vol 2

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: How can diverse societies guarantee inclusiveness? Descriptive representation – that is, whether an individual shares a social characteristic with her elected representative – is advocated as an effective part of the solution. It has been shown to foster political stability, trust, participation, and efficacy, particularly among groups that have been historically marginalized (Gay, 2002; Mansbridge, 1999; Schwindt- Bayer and Mishler, 2005; West, 2017). The effects of descriptive representation have been said to go beyond the political realm and may empower disadvantaged social groups in all aspects of life. Empowerment arises with the existence of role models, a change in the level of expected discrimination, and altered beliefs about how much governmental institutions enforce anti-discrimination policies (among others, Marx, Ko and Friedman (2009)). Our study (1) experimentally varies whether women’s descriptive representation in national parliaments around the world is framed as positive achievement (positive frame treatment) or reason for concern (negative frame treatment) or not at all (no frame treatment) and, then, in a laboratory experiment, (2) elicits subjects’ willingness to complete a math task for a fixed piece rate (1 token per correctly solved addition) or a variable piece rate (0.5 to 1.5 token as chosen by the male experimenter upon reviewing subjects’ demographic information and performance in a math pre-test). The positive frame treatment illustrates the increase of 13% in female members of national parliaments around the world from 1990 to 2018 as success while the negative frame illustrates the 76% male members in 2018 as vast underrepresentation of women).

q16.value: Main hypotheses: (H1) We predict an increase of women’s preference for completing the math task under the variable piece rate when receiving the positive frame treatment over negative frame and no frame treatments. We further expect (H2) women’s performance in pre- and main math task to be better as well as their belief in their relative ability to be stronger in the positive frame than the negative and no frame treatments. (H3) Finally, we expect an decrease in women’s belief that they are likely to be discriminated against, and only a slight increase (magnitude less than discrimination belief) in their beliefs about their relative performance (H4). Heterogeneous treatment effects: Treatment effects (on men and women) are expected to vary with subjects’ gender identification, gender role models, collective self-esteem, and beliefs in gender group marginalisation. Mechanism: The effects of the positive frame treatment on women will run through either of the following mechanism: Increased self-efficacy, increased self-esteem, decreased expectation of discrimination, or increased presence of female role models.

q17.value: Upon entering the laboratory, subjects answer a range of socio-demographic questions (including gender) and political attitudes questions, and we elicit their risk preference using a standard Holt/Laury (2002, AER)-list. Then, they are randomly assigned to the positive frame, negative frame, or no frame treatments (random assignment blocked on gender). Subjects in the no frame treatment advance directly to the two math tasks while we elicit from subjects in the positive/negative frame treatment further self-reported measures on subjects’ beliefs about gender identification, gender role models, collective self-esteem, and gender group marginalisation (moderator variables) as well as about self-efficacy, expected discrimination in society, role models, and self-esteem (Mediator/Mechanism) variables. The treatment screen (positive/negative frame) is shown between moderator and mediator variables. We recruit women and men from the subject pool at a ratio of 2:1. After the survey, subjects in the positive/negative frame treatment advance to the two math tasks. Conversely, subjects in the “no frame” condition take the survey after they complete those two tasks (so as not to prime them). The two tasks are monetized and contain adding two two-digit numbers. In the pre-math task, subjects receive 1 token for each correctly added number. In the main math task, they can choose between receiving 1 token or a by the experimenter chosen rate from the range 0.5 to 1.5 (outcome measure 1). We also elicit their belief about the percentage of other participants who scored lower than they did (outcome measure 2) and look at their score in both math tasks (outcome measure 3). The average treatment effect of the positive frame treatment is evaluated by a difference-in-proportions (choice fixed rate vs experimenter-set variable rate) and difference-in-distribution tests (performance, belief about relative performance) as well as appropriate regression models which include moderator, mediator, order of task variables, and risk preferences..

q2.value: Zach Mohr | Jaclyn Piatak | Suzanne Leland

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q16.value: Our experimental study examines how privatization and deservingness influence blame attribution in the delivery of public services. We use a timely experiment of prisoner transportation, where both conditions have been in the news as of late so are based on real scenarios. In our 2 X 2 experiment, we vary 1) whether the transportation is provided by the government or a for-profit firm and 2) whether the prisoner died due to negligence in transport or the prisoner escaped and killed an innocent bystander due to negligence in transport. Findings have implications for research and practice on blame attribution and the role of deservingness in shaping public opinion. Our first hypothesis is that citizens will place greater blame on the government than the contractor. Our second hypothesis is that citizens’ blame will be higher when the bystander is killed than when the prisoner dies.

q17.value: We will examine the data descriptively with crosstabs and with regression to control for potential confounding factors, like political orientation.

q27.value: The experiment will be conducted by POLS-Lab at UNCC and will use MTURK to get people to take the experiment.

attributes.title: Social Identity and Perceptions of Terrorism in the United States

q1.value: Social Identity and Perceptions of Terrorism in the United States

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This survey experiment intends to test whether people living in the United States are more likely to designate a perpetrator of mass murder as a "terrorist" when that individual fits a certain social identity frame.

q16.value: My hypothesis is that people in the United States will be more likely to describe a person of apparently Muslim/Arab descent as a terrorist than a person of white/European descent, even if the act for which each is being judged is exactly the same. Furthermore, I hypothesize that the discrepancy between responses to each situation will be more stark among the older, white, male Republican respondents, while the discrepancy will be less noticeable among the younger, non-white, female Democratic or Independent respondents.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested through a survey experiment in which respondents will be presented with a vignette about an act of mass murder. Respondents will be given some information about the act itself, the number of casualties, and the name of the perpetrator. Respondents will be randomly assigned to one of two vignettes--the only difference between the two vignettes will be the name of the perpetrator--in one version, he will have an Anglo/European name; in the other version, he will have a Muslim/Arab name. After reading the vignette, respondents will be asked if they would define the perpetrator as a terrorist. To test my hypothesis, I will compare the data collected from each version of the survey.

q19.value: 400-600 (if 600 responses can be collected within two weeks, this is ideal. If not, 400 is the minimum)

attributes.title: The Local Labor Market Effects of the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004

q1.value: The Local Labor Market Effects of the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004

q2.value: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato | Timothy Rickert

q5.value: We would like to thank Jennifer Blouin and Linda Krull for bringing the AJCA to our attention and for generously sharing their data

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The AJCA provided a brief tax holiday for US firms that led to a drastic increase in repatriation. Several studies have analyzed how these repatriations were spent (Blouin & Krull 2009, Dharmapala et al. 2011), however, no one has explored the potential employment effects of the Act. For more information, see our pre-analysis plan.

q16.value: We implement a research design similar to Garrett et al. 2019, intended to measure the local labor market effects of these repatriations. We intend to analyze the effects on employment, income inequality, and earnings. For precise specifications, see our pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: We use an event study regression design on a variety of outcomes. Full details are in our pre-analysis plan.

q19.value: Around 300 repatriating firms and 300 matched control firms, for around 600 firms total.

attributes.title: Who Shall Be Allowed to Vote?

q1.value: Who Shall Be Allowed to Vote?

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Universal suffrage is the cornerstone of democracy. But what does this ‘universal’ mean? In the study at hand, we formulate testable hypotheses based the main lines of normative theory on democratic inclusion, to study their popular support. The support for each normative principle is tapped by means of a conjoint analysis.

q16.value: We test the popular support for 1) the membership principle, according to which citizenship should be decisive for enfranchisement, 2) the all affected and all subjected principles, according to which (at least) all residents should be enfranchised, and 3) the contributivist principle according to which all tax payers should be enfranchised. We also measure and control for the support for letting enfranchisement by decided by three other traits: country of origin, law abidance, and education.

q17.value: By a means of a population based sample of 1,000 US respondents, a conjoint analysis calculates how respondents’ preferences to enfranchise a fictional person are affected if the fictional person is citizen, resident, tax payer, born in the US, respectively, and by the fictional person’s gender and level of education. The first three of the fictional persons traits tap the extent to which Americans implicitly support the hypothesized principles: citizenship (membership principle), residency (all affected and all subjected principle) and taxpaying (contributivist principle). The effect of each trait of the fictional person is isolated from the effects of the other traits. The salience of each criterion for enfranchisement is compared to the salience of each other criterion.

q24.value: Dnr 2017/480 (Regional Ethical Review Board, Uppsala, Sweden)

attributes.title: Evaluating Community Policing in the Philippines: Communication, Trust, and Service Provision

q1.value: Evaluating Community Policing in the Philippines: Communication, Trust, and Service Provision

q2.value: Dotan Haim | Matthew Nanes | Nico Ravanilla

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: How can community-oriented policing (COP) practices be implemented in a way that sustainably increases trust in the police and reduces crime in areas where state legitimacy is low? In this study, we test the effect of a COP program that combines community engagement (CEP) and problem-oriented policing (POP). We also probe two additional moderating factors that we posit will increase the sustainability of the program: 1) collaboration between national police forces and local community officers charged with implementing the program, and 2) public recognition and top-down accountability mechanisms incentivizing police units to follow through on addressing community needs. We implement our study in Sorsogon Province of the Philippines, where state legitimacy is challenged by an active communist rebel group and where the drug war implemented by President Rodrigo Duterte has resulted in a significant erosion of trust in the police.

q16.value: Generally, do various components of community policing increase citizen trust in the police, increase citizen communication with the police, and decrease crime rates. See PAP for details.

q17.value: We conduct a series of experiments in Sorsogon Province, Philippines, in which we assign community policing programs to randomly-selected barangays. We conduct surveys of civilians and police officers both before and after the programs in both treatment and control barangays, and collect administrative data on crime in both treatment and control barangays, to test whether the presence of the community policing programs affects attitudes towards the police, public safety outcomes, and other indicators.

q27.value: Innovations for Poverty Action Sorsogon and Philippine National Police Sorsogon Provincial Police Office

attributes.title: Party Leader Influence and Conflicting Signals in Opinion Formation

q1.value: Party Leader Influence and Conflicting Signals in Opinion Formation

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

registration_responses.q1: Party Leader Influence and Conflicting Signals in Opinion Formation
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

q2.value: Sirianne Dahlum | Jonathan Pinckney | Tore Wig

q5.value: We are grateful to the following people for comments and feedback: Scott Gates, Kristian Skrede Gleditsch, Marianne Dahl, Håvard Mokleiv Nygård, Charles Butcher, Ingrid Vik Bakken, Erica Chenoweth, Robert Johns, Jessica Maves Braithwaite

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: An emerging consensus holds that non-violent protests outperform violent ones when it comes to recruiting participants and supporters. As a result, nonviolent protest movements are generally considered more likely to achieve goals such as regime-change and democracy. Yet few studies consider the individual-level logics behind support for nonviolent (or violent) protest. We conduct an experiment to investigate whether nonviolent (rather than violent) resistance induces support for protest movements, and, if so, why. We focus on two distinct logics for why individuals will prefer nonviolent resistance: A strategic logic whereby non-violent mobilization is chosen for instrumental reasons, and an intrinsic logic where non-violence is chosen for its intrinsic moral superiority. To elicit responses consistent with these two logics, we propose a multi-factorial vignette experiment among respondents in a non-protest setting. Here, we present respondents with hypothetical scenarios of protest movements facing autocratic governments, and ask them whether they support, would join, or want to contribute to, a particular movement, contingent on randomly varying movement characteristics.

q16.value: The project tests two hypotheses, one corresponding to an instrumentalist logic (where the consequences of non-violent protest are emphasized) and one corresponding to an intrinsic logic (where non-violence increases support for protest regardless of consequences). These are our overarching theoretical hypotheses (and they can be broken down into three more concrete hypotheses, as we elaborate on below). The two overarching theoretical hypotheses are formulated like this: (Instrumentalist logic) H1: Nonviolence increases individual preferences for participation in protest, and this effect (partly) is moderated by positive expected campaign- and individual-level consequences. (Intrinsic logic) H2: Nonviolence increases preferences for participation regardless of campaign- and individual-level consequences The outcomes of interest are whether respondents support the protesters, would be willing to join them, and whether they would be willing to donate to the movement (see the pre-analysis plan for details). The theoretical hypotheses break down into more concrete hypotheses, corresponding to the statistical model to be tested. We include the following treatment variables: Nonviolence/violence (N), No repression/repression (R), success/no success (S). We estimate: Y = B_0 + B_1N + B_2R + B_3S + B _4N *R + B_5N* S + ε Our specific hypotheses are: Hypothesis Label Coefficient Expected sign H1a: Non-violence/success B_5N* S >0 (positive) H1b: Non-violence/repression B _4N *R 0 (positive)

q17.value: These will be tested in an OLS model, where the unit of analysis is the respondent. For further details, see the pre-analysis plan.

q18.value: In different countries (that are in the pool of respondents on the prolific academic online platform).

q24.value: The experiment has been approved by the Norwegian Social Science Data service.

attributes.title: Effects of temporary residence permits and family reunions on refugees' education and employment

q1.value: Effects of temporary residence permits and family reunions on refugees' education and employment

q2.value: Linna Marten | Jens Hainmueller | Dominik Hangartner

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Until 2016, Sweden, unlike most other European countries, provided almost all individuals who were declared to be refugees or in need of subsidiary protection with a permanent residence permit and the option of applying for family reunion. A new asylum law, adopted by the Swedish Parliament in June 2016 drastically changed the regulation. The right to asylum is intact under the new law, but the possibility to reunite with family members is restricted and temporary permits are the new norm. Importantly, the rules depend not only on whether a case was decided before or after the law was implemented, on July 20th 2016, but also on whether the application was submitted before November 25th 2015. We will examine how the new law affected individuals' economic outcomes.

q16.value: Receiving a temporary residence permit rather than a permanent one, as well as not being able to reunite with ones family, is likely to contribute to a high degree of uncertainty and stress for the affected individuals. This can make it harder to plan for a life in Sweden, and decrease incentives to invest in education and search for employment. We will examine the effect of being exposed to the new law on employment, earnings, language training, and education.

q17.value: We will use data from STATIV, an administrative database developed by Statistics Sweden (SCB) together with the Swedish Migration Agency. We will focus on individuals arriving within 60 days before and after the November 25th 2015 cutoff, and individuals whose application was decided within 60 days before and after the July 20th 2016 cutoff. Since the rules differ for different subgroups, both depending on protection status (refugee status or subsidiary protection) and age (adults with/without children under age 18 and unaccompanied minors), we will estimate the effect both for the pooled sample and for different subgroups. Using a regression-discontinuity design, we will estimate the effect of being subject to the new legislation, meaning that it is is highly unlikely that the individual is eligible for a permanent residence permit and (for those with subsidiary protection) family reunion.

registration_responses.q1: Effects of temporary residence permits and family reunions on refugees' education and employment
registration_responses.q2: Linna Marten | Jens Hainmueller | Dominik Hangartner
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Until 2016, Sweden, unlike most other European countries, provided almost all individuals who were declared to be refugees or in need of subsidiary protection with a permanent residence permit and the option of applying for family reunion. A new asylum law, adopted by the Swedish Parliament in June 2016 drastically changed the regulation. The right to asylum is intact under the new law, but the possibility to reunite with family members is restricted and temporary permits are the new norm. Importantly, the rules depend not only on whether a case was decided before or after the law was implemented, on July 20th 2016, but also on whether the application was submitted before November 25th 2015. We will examine how the new law affected individuals' economic outcomes.
registration_responses.q16: Receiving a temporary residence permit rather than a permanent one, as well as not being able to reunite with ones family, is likely to contribute to a high degree of uncertainty and stress for the affected individuals. This can make it harder to plan for a life in Sweden, and decrease incentives to invest in education and search for employment. We will examine the effect of being exposed to the new law on employment, earnings, language training, and education.
registration_responses.q17: We will use data from STATIV, an administrative database developed by Statistics Sweden (SCB) together with the Swedish Migration Agency. We will focus on individuals arriving within 60 days before and after the November 25th 2015 cutoff, and individuals whose application was decided within 60 days before and after the July 20th 2016 cutoff. Since the rules differ for different subgroups, both depending on protection status (refugee status or subsidiary protection) and age (adults with/without children under age 18 and unaccompanied minors), we will estimate the effect both for the pooled sample and for different subgroups. Using a regression-discontinuity design, we will estimate the effect of being subject to the new legislation, meaning that it is is highly unlikely that the individual is eligible for a permanent residence permit and (for those with subsidiary protection) family reunion.
